Articles.Content:
Start a career save with gravity set at 0.01 G at all times using Alt-F12 hack gravity. Remember that this resets when you reopen the game, so turn on hack gravity in another save and load from there.

The goal is to land Kerbals on as many worlds as possible and bring them safely back to Kerbin. Getting science or upgrading facilities is good, but by no means the goal. Exploration is.

Remember that SOIs behave quite differently than normal. Specifically, they act as if the planet or moon is moving at 10% speed even though it isn't.

Edited June 17, 2020 by Pds314
Sooooo, obviously it is possible to hit all of the bodies (though some, like Gilly, will take forever in real time, and some boss level sniping). Is there a scoring system or other goal?
This sounds really fun - most of the time, people make challenges to do higher gravity, making it hard on purpose. For this, the goal is just to see how far you can go and see. I'm on board!

I think Caveman-style iterative quicksave and transfer might work as well. Where you miss and then use the information from that miss to hit the next time. Keep in mind however that planets still move just as much as they normally do. Hack gravity doesn't affect planetary orbit speeds. It does however affect how their SOI transfers momentum. So you don't get automatically flung into deep space by exiting Kerbin SOI, but you might get stuck in front of Kerbin SOI as it keeps bumping into you, and just "pushing forward" would require about 8 km/s if delta-V, flinging you into deep space. Long story short, you always want to leave through the back of planetary SOIs because they're kinda acting like warp bubbles.
